claim: Pangolin scales do not appear to be an effective medicine for curing any conditions.

supporting.text: Scientific studies have found no evidence that pangolin scales have medicinal properties for treating any medical conditions.

attacks.text: Scientific studies have found no evidence that pangolin scales have medicinal properties for treating any medical conditions.
Traditional Chinese medicine has historically used pangolin scales for various treatments, suggesting some perceived efficacy.
Historical use does not equate to scientifically validated efficacy, and many traditional remedies lack empirical support.
Some preliminary studies suggest potential bioactive compounds in pangolin scales, though further research is needed.
Preliminary findings are insufficient to claim efficacy, and no peer-reviewed studies confirm medicinal benefits.

supporting.text: Pangolin scales are primarily composed of keratin, the same protein found in human hair and nails, which has no known therapeutic effects.

attacks.text: Pangolin scales are primarily composed of keratin, the same protein found in human hair and nails, which has no known therapeutic effects.
Traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) has used pangolin scales for centuries to treat conditions like lactation difficulties and arthritis, suggesting perceived efficacy.
Modern clinical studies have found no scientific evidence supporting the medicinal efficacy of pangolin scales for any condition.
Keratin may have indirect benefits when processed or combined with other ingredients in traditional remedies.
No peer-reviewed research demonstrates that processed keratin from pangolin scales has unique pharmacological properties compared to other sources.

supporting.text: Major health organizations, including the WHO, do not recognize pangolin scales as a valid treatment for any diseases.

attacks.text: Major health organizations, including the WHO, do not recognize pangolin scales as a valid treatment for any diseases.
Traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) has historically used pangolin scales for various treatments, suggesting some cultural or historical efficacy.
Modern scientific studies have found no evidence supporting the medicinal efficacy of pangolin scales in TCM or other practices.
The lack of recognition by major health organizations could be due to insufficient research rather than proven inefficacy.
Extensive research on similar animal-derived treatments has consistently shown no significant medical benefits, making it unlikely that pangolin scales are an exception.

supporting.text: Traditional medicine practices that use pangolin scales lack empirical support from clinical trials or peer-reviewed research.

attacks.text: Traditional medicine practices that use pangolin scales lack empirical support from clinical trials or peer-reviewed research.
Some traditional medicine practitioners report anecdotal success with pangolin scales, suggesting potential efficacy not yet captured by modern research methods.
Anecdotal evidence is prone to placebo effects and confirmation bias, making it unreliable without controlled studies.
Historical use of pangolin scales in traditional medicine spans centuries, indicating a form of long-term observational validation.
Historical use does not equate to efficacy; many historically used remedies have been debunked by modern science (e.g., bloodletting).

supporting.text: The illegal trade of pangolin scales is driven by demand for unproven remedies rather than evidence-based medical benefits.

attacks.text: The illegal trade of pangolin scales is driven by demand for unproven remedies rather than evidence-based medical benefits.
